intro: Lepturus incurvatus, commonly known as the curly-leaved water plantain, is a herbaceous aquatic plant native to freshwater environments in North America. It typically grows in shallow, slow-moving waters and has slender, ribbon-like leaves that curl inward, giving it its common name. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that bloom in late summer, and it is often found in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of ponds. Its roots help stabilize the soil, making it an important species for aquatic ecosystem health. Lepturus incurvatus is also used in traditional medicine by some indigenous communities for its purported healing properties.
